body: I tested this directly on MXNet master without any of my changes.

For custom to work on cpu, environment variable MXNET_CPU_WORKER_NTHREADS needs to be at least 2.
I'm working on a fix to remove this dependency

The 20160419_win10_x64_gpu also worked on my win 8 machine. So perhaps you already fixed it.

If you are still interested I also built mxnet on my win8 machine with the current source code (18-5-2016).
Can you see anything from my compiled binary ?

I can confirm that running `custom_softmax.py` works perfectly (on GPU) with this commit. 

I have also obviously ensured that my Python is using this commits version of MXNet (I used print statements in the new `operator.py` to confirm).

lgtm
On Wed, May 18, 2016 at 10:54 AM Eric Junyuan Xie notifications@github.com
wrote:

> LGTM. @mli https://github.com/mli Could you have a look and lets merge
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2165#issuecomment-220107117
As this been implemented or do I still need to use the suggested workaround?

first,you shoud use:

``` [python]
X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 2)
X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 1)
```

then when using im2rec, it default using tquality=0.8 for image compression(maybe it will hurt the color), you can change it to 1.0 and debug again.

last, please show the original image at the same time.

if you mean at predict phase,you can add it easily, first you set up a table(class_number, tag), then when the  model output the class number, you look up the table to find the corresponding tag, and print it out.

I tried swapaxes(), Here they are! no resize this time.
![after im2rec](https://github.com/ShawnXuan/images/blob/master/new.jpg?raw=true)
![original image](https://github.com/ShawnXuan/images/blob/master/original.JPG?raw=true)
Thanks!

While compiling with cudnn v2, I got the error:
/mxnet/mshadow/mshadow/./base.h:276:45: error: 'CUDNN_DATA_HALF' was not declared in this scope
   static const cudnnDataType_t kCudnnFlag = CUDNN_DATA_HALF;
                                             ^

@tornadomeet 
Hi, thanks a lot for your reply! I think your method solves my problem. I really appreciate it! Besides, I am wondering whether it is possible print out the image after each convolutional layer?

I remember Mu has done some work on it.

let's rebase and merge @sxjscience
I don't think any one is on it. cudnn lstm is of higher priority but no one is on it yet either
Hi, @tqchen @winstywang @piiswrong @mavenlin, is this problem sovled about round operation in convolution and pool?
@tqchen would you please give some suggestions on how to modify it? I'm hoping for this function. Thanks.
I've rebased @piiswrong

Sorry to bother, but now is cudnn v4 supported?

Cheers!

it seems that you have multi output
the label depends on what loss layer do you use, if you use softmax loss, then the label is the maximum index, you can check https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/amalgamation/python/mxnet_predict.py
X is 4 dim, you should change it to 3 dim first
yes,it will generate auto.  you just need give the mean file name.

@thirdwing Any progress on this? 

R users definitely prefer high-level API. I suspect that many people are willing to build networks by themselves.

``` python
_, model_args, model_auxs = mx.model.load_checkpoint(“model/lenet”, 166)
for k in model_args:
    # k = fc2_weight fc2_bias conv1_weight ...
    a = model_args[k]
    b = a.asnumpy()           # b is a numpy array
    np.savetxt('b.txt', b)    # play b with any numpy function
```
@dsqx71 answers the question precisely
c.f. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/rcnn
closing this issue for now, as many of them are now supported thanks to our amazing contributors. Let us open it as more requests come in, or start another issue
@liubenyuan Can you show the full log? The info is too little.
it sums over the entire tensor, including the batch dimension
When was v0.5?
It was the first release of mxnet
Because there is no synchronization point, you are pushing too many operations into the engine. Add a executor.outputs[0].wait_to_read() before forward
Thank you for the replies. I ended up using a customized `PrefetchingIter` for my use case.

You have to comment the line `#include <cblas.h>` in file mxnet_predict-all.cc and run make again. Furthermore Javascript version doesn't use cblas, I successfully compile JS version with make MIN=1. Probably a clean solution is to modify amalgamation.py excluding the cblas include with MIN=1.

In case of runtime errors see this issue that I've recently encountered with mxnet.js #2178

I think it is good to also have a NEWS.md or ChangLog.md to summarize the release dates and main changes in each release.

Btw: why skipping 0.6? 

Also I think it is good to have convention of the version number. Julia kind of have major.minor.issue convention. Maybe we can look around and adopt a convention.

I was running some tests..sometime it hangs. I was wondering how the data is split across workers? Does all them get equal number of iterations? otherwise some of them can get stuck and others dont arrive
Also the Sphinx doc can be versioned, we need to remember updating the version number there.

many thanks

@pluskid I agree that a NEWS.md is needed.  The version number just jumps out as there is a lot of things happening since the first release, so we feel maybe that worth more than 0.1

The whole iterator is 4 dimensions, and the X is 3 dimensions. the original pics are 3 dimensions. Thank you very much for your patient! 
test code is:

``` python
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
#import os

batch_size = 40
data_shape = (3, 480, 640)#(784, )

data_dir = ""#+os.getcwd()+"/"

test_iter = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
            path_imgrec = data_dir + "test_images.rec",
            path_imglist= data_dir + "test_images.lst",
            data_shape  = data_shape,
            batch_size  = batch_size,
            shuffle     = True,
            flat        = True)
X_test = test_iter.getdata().asnumpy()
print X_test.shape
for i in range(10):
    plt.subplot(1,10,i+1)
    X=X_test[i]
    print "before:", X.shape
    X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 2)
    X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 1)
    print "after:", X.shape
    plt.imshow(X)        
    plt.axis('off')
plt.show()
```

output is:

```
[00:59:19] src/io/iter_image_recordio.cc:67: Loaded ImageList from test_images.lst 40 Image records
[00:59:19] src/io/iter_image_recordio.cc:212: ImageRecordIOParser: test_images.rec, use 1 threads for decoding..

before: (3, 480, 640)

```

yes, on a single machine each gpu has equal number of iterations. i also
saw hanging happens sometimes months ago, i guess its due to bug of nccl

> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1074#issuecomment-220484035

1. refer to http://mxnet.dmlc.ml/en/latest/system/multi_node.html
2. the number of servers doesn't matter too much
3. picking a random one is often fine

> 
> Seems that small batch size have bad effect on the efficiency.
> I would test with imageNet to get better comprehension of those issue.
> 
> Still have some question:
> 1、 "the effective batch size for sync is num_node \* batch_size", how about
> the effective batch size for async mode?
> 2、 how much server and worker to used for better performance ?
> I think that the parameter server is used for release the communication
> pressure of many workers' pulling and pushing to one server, but too much
> server would cause the sync communication to become huge, is that right? It
> seems that the default setting is the same number of worker and server， is
> that the best practice setting?
> I test the same number of worker with different number of server, there
> isn't obvious change of the efficiency.
> 3、 it save model on every nodes, which to used or they are the same?
> This is quite a dump question but my cluster environment is sharing one
> file system, and the saved model is all named the same and keep covered by
> the latest node model, so I can't check it myself.
> 
> @mli https://github.com/mli @piiswrong https://github.com/piiswrong
> thanks a lots.
>

@pluskid @piiswrong @antinucleon @mli I have created news.md here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/NEWS.md

Please help fill in things that you find missing. Let us tag a new version once the change list are ready and change our way of versioning starting this point
I think @pluskid have quite a lot of experience in versioning. Maybe you can give a proposal on how we should do versioning and we can keep the rule as we move on

Thanks for your reply @piiswrong.  The code is running successfully now. 
I found another way to make code running without memory error by replacing `vgg_model.data[:] = mx.nd.array(data["mix"],ctx=args.ctx)` with `vgg_model.data[:] = data["mix"])`. But i don't know the second way is right or not.
assign from or to numpy array is always synchronization. Usually you will always want to copy data out to CPU, and that will be a synchronization and it is good to do so
@SlipknotTN Do you mind to send a PR to fix this? Thanks!

Thanks @tqchen ! Let's do major.minor.issue then. Let us call the next release v0.7.0.
- major: for major releases (e.g. when we feel ready to have a v1.0.0 release) or big breaking changes
- minor: some big updates
- issue: mostly for bugfixing quick releases

In our experience, one way to get NCCL deadlocks is if device synchronization occurs (e.g. a call to cudaMalloc/cudaFree) concurrently while the NCCL collective kernels are being launched across devices.
sounds good. I also find the milestone tag could be useful to group possible roadmaps needed fro minor version updates.

that may happen since the engine can have multiple threads. i thought
cudaMalloc/cudaFree
was thread-safe. or it's NCCL's fault to break that assumption

I'm also stuck here. @piiswrong: Can you please provide some code sample for the weighted loss? Thanks.

You can achieve the same thing by grouping several SoftmaxLoss layers and using `grad_scale` for the weighting of the losses.

``` julia
softmax1 = mx.SoftmaxOutput(..., grad_scale = 0.67)
softmax2 = mx.SoftmaxOutput(..., grad_scale = 0.33)
net = mx.Group(softmax1, softmax2)
```

Hello, is there an alternative ? 
I'm trying to compose various layers by low-level primitives. Sum seems to be indispensible.
The only thing I can come up with now is a FullyConnectedLayer with weights fixed at 1.
But that seems to be overkill.

Or could I do Reshape to (128, Layeroutput, 1)
And then do sum_mid_internal and after that a reshape to 128, 1

Still a bit cumbersome but this might work.
Now,I just ignore it,because if i open a new terminal it will be OK.

When you compile JS lib with emscripten you don't add openblas dependencies. OpenBLAS is used for Android and iOS version with MIN=0.
So JS version should work also without BLAS.
it's very strange! i'll test it tomorrow whether this can be produced.

FYI 

```
Reshape to (128, Layeroutput, 1)
sum_mid_internal
Reshape to (128, 1)
```

Worked.
Not ideal but manageble
Ok
@eaplatanios Could you make a PR for the reshape operator? We are willing to keep scala package up to date, we are just short of hands.
For BatchNorm layer, do we need to share their auxiliary states as well?

@ziyeqinghan @thirdwing Sorry for not bring this up up-front. But it would be great if you can contribute a tutorial on how to use this feature like others in http://mxnet.dmlc.ml/en/latest/packages/r/index.html#tutorials

@ShawnXuan Hello, i just test it, when using opencv to save the image, it is OK! just add one line after plt.imshow(X)  :

```
X = cv2.cvtColor(X, cv2.COLOR_RGB2BGR)
cv2.imwrite("result.png", X)
```

I checked the json file, if deleting the item of `"shape":"()"`, it will be fine. 

Seems to be deprecating issue. I will leave this open for you to see whether it's bug or not.
@mli @piiswrong can you review this?
sounds great! thanks!

It is normal, because most mxnet operator are asynchronous, which means they do not block until the operation finishes. Instead, there dependency is tracked.

asnumpy introduce a synchronization, which need to wait all previous operations to finish
there is not an explicit transform, instead it runs a sparse matrix multiplication implicitly
Thanks. So if I still want to report training accuracy without significant performance hit, like only report every x batches, is there an easy way to do that?
I forgot to point out that I am under Captain.
If you are using `model.FeedForward`, you can get all weights dictionary by getting `m.arg_params`, where `m` is the model
Great, thanks! Do I need to do anything to make it not optimize out those layers? Basically I want to extract all of the weights from my first convolution layer.
No. Weight will not be optimized out :)
we currently don't have a profiler. You can try adding it in graph_executor.
@antinucleon Seems to be a default value problem?
Seems so. Will fix it tonight.
@sbodenstein have you successfully use warp-ctc in mxnet?
LGTM
